aif:I-node.aif:claimText: There is no record of viruses closely related to SARS-CoV-2 in any laboratory before December 2019, or genomes that in combination could provide a SARS-CoV-2 genome.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: No record of viruses closely related to SARS-CoV-2 in any laboratory

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: Humans infected with SARS-CoV-2 shed virus through faeces and can have gastrointestinal symptoms, suggesting involvement of the gastrointestinal tract.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Humans shed SARS-CoV-2 through faeces

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: While there is some evidence for possible reintroduction of SARS-CoV-2 through handling of imported contaminated frozen products in China since the initial pandemic wave, this would be extraordinary in 2019 where the virus was not widely circulating.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Virus not widely circulating

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: SARS-CoV-2 has been identified in an increasing number of animal species, but genetic and epidemiological studies have suggested that these were infections introduced from humans, rather than enzootic virus circulation.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Animal infections introduced from humans

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: Industrial food production has high levels of hygiene criteria and is regularly audited.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Food production hygiene

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: Foodborne outbreaks with enteric viruses are common, and - when entering the food supply - may lead to geographically dispersed outbreaks that can be difficult to detect.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Foodborne outbreaks with enteric viruses are common

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: In high-density farms, there often are connections between farms (for instance, through the workforce and food supply), leading to complex transmission pathways that may be difficult to unravel, as was observed in other zoonotic outbreaks involving farmed animals.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: High-density farms

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: SARS-CoV-2 is transmitted from an animal reservoir to an animal host, followed by subsequent spread within that intermediate host (spillover host), and then transmission to humans. The passage through an intermediate host can be with or without virus adaptation.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Introduction through intermediate host

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: There is no evidence of infection in any of the animals tested following the Wuhan outbreak.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: No animal infection

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: There was a large network of domesticated wild animal farms, supplying farmed wildlife to Wuhan.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Wild animal farms

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: The majority of emerging diseases originate from animal reservoirs and there is strong evidence that most of the current human coronaviruses have originated from animals.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Most human coronaviruses originate in animals

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: These [enteric transmission] processes have been investigated widely for non-enveloped viruses but far less for enveloped viruses in the food chain, but there is widespread evidence for SARS-CoV-2 nucleic acid in sewage.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Evidence for SARS-CoV-2 nucleic acid in sewage

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: The Wuhan CDC laboratory moved on 2nd December 2019 to a new location near the Huanan market. Such moves can be disruptive for the operations of any laboratory.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: The Wuhan CDC laboratory moved on 2nd December 2019

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: When working in particular with virus cultures, but also with animal inoculations or clinical samples, humans could become infected in laboratories with limited biosafety, poor laboratory management practice, or following negligence.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Laboratory infection could happen

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: Although many betacoronavirus sequences have been found in a range of bats, isolation of viruses from them is rare, and only a few of the identified full genomes have human ACE2 binding properties.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Isolation of viruses from bats is rare

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: The RaTG13 and pangolin coronaviruses do bind to hACE2, although the fit is not optimal.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Animal coronavirus can bind to hACE2

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: There has been speculation regarding the presence of human ACE2 receptor binding and a furin-cleavage site in SARS-CoV-2, but both have been found in animal viruses as well, and elements of the furin-cleavage site are present in RmYN02 and the new Thailand bat SARSr-CoV.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Speculation about bio-engineering

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: High-density farming is common in many places across the world and includes many livestock species as well as farmed wildlife.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: High-density farming

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: SARS-CoV-2 is introduced through a laboratory incident, reflecting an accidental infection of staff from laboratory activities involving the relevant viruses.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Introduction through a laboratory incident

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: Many animal CoVs have dual respiratory and enteric tropism.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Animal CoV enteric tropism

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: Since the containment of SARS-CoV-2 in China, new outbreaks have occurred for which genomic sequence data was generated. Based on epidemiological analysis and genetic sequencing of viruses from new cases throughout 2020, there is no evidence of repeated introduction of early SARS-CoV-2 strains of potential animal origins into humans in China.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: No evidence of repeated introduction from animals

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: Seeding of SARS-CoV-2 in mink populations has shown that these animals are highly susceptible as well and the current evidence available cannot rule out the possibility for minks as the primary source of SARS-CoV-2.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Mink susceptible to SARS-CoV-2

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: Seafood is known as a source of foodborne outbreaks, and food as a vehicle of zoonotic infections.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Seafood is known as a source of foodborne outbreaks

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: Humans can also be exposed to contaminated fomites, as suggested from the studies on markets in China in 2020.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Humans exposed to contaminated fomites

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: Sewage treatment typically does not remove all infectious viruses prior to release of wastewater in the environment.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Sewage treatment does not remove all viruses

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: Screening programmes have found some limited evidence for the presence of SARS-CoV-2 by nucleotide acid tests in different batches of unopened packages and containers in different cities.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Screening of packaging

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: Both these putative hosts are infrequently in contact with humans, and an intermediary step involving an amplifying host has been observed for several other emerging viruses (Henipaviruses, influenzaviruses, SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV). SARS-CoV-2 infection and intraspecies spread (including further transmission to humans) has been documented in an increasing number of animal species, particularly mustelids and felids.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Amplifying host for other viruses

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: Since the near-elimination of SARS-CoV-2 in China, the country has experienced some outbreaks related to imported frozen products in 2020.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Outbreaks related to imported frozen products

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: Recently, two distinct types of SARSr-CoV were detected in Malayan pangolin (M. Javanica sampled in rescue centres in China for smuggled imported wildlife).
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Similar virus in pangolin

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: There is some literature suggesting SARS-CoV-2 may have been circulating earlier as indicated by sewage testing in Spain and Italy.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Sewage testing in Spain and Italy

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: Surveys of the bat virome conducted following the SARS epidemic in 2003 have found SARSr-CoV in various bats, particularly Rhinolophus bats, and viruses with the high genetic similarity to SARS-CoV-2 have been found in Rhinolophus bats sampled in China in 2013, Japan in 2013, Thailand in 2020 and Cambodia in 2010.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Similar virus in bats

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: There is transmission of SARS-CoV-2 (or very closely-related progenitor virus) from an animal reservoir host to human, followed by direct person-to-person transmission with or without the need for adaptation of the virus to humans. The speed of dissemination will depend on chance events such as superspreading events.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Direct zoonotic transmission

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: In the epidemiological investigation of Qingdao outbreak, the live virus was isolated from the outer package of imported frozen products.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Live virus on packaging

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: The increasing number of animals shown to be susceptible to SARS-CoV-2 includes animals that are farmed in sufficient densities to allow potential for enzootic circulation.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Enzootic circulation

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: The closest relatives of SARS-CoV-2 from bats and pangolin are evolutionarily distant from SARS-CoV-2.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Closest relatives of SARS-CoV-2 are evolutionarily distant

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: Risk-assessments have concluded that the risk of foodborne transmission of SARS-CoV-2 through these known transmission pathways is very low in comparison with respiratory transmission.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Low risk of foodborne transmission

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: Because several contact residues between the bat and pangolin viruses and the hACE2 receptor are distinct from those in SARS-CoV-2, the affinity is low, and the viruses are genetically still quite distinct from SARS–CoV-2.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: SARSr-CoVs genetically distinct from SARS–CoV-2

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: Screening of farmed wildlife was limited but did not provide conclusive evidence for the existence of circulation.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: No evidence for SARS-CoV-2 in farmed wildlife

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: Optimized conditions for sustained virus transmission chains in large-scale animal farms may also impact on virus seasonality in favour of a year-round endemic transmission pattern, and thereby increasing the zoonotic risk in winter months.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Virus transmission chains in animal farms

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: For SARS, food animal handlers had increased prevalence of SARS-CoV-specific antibodies.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: SARS-CoV-specific antibodies in food animal handlers

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: Bats are a known reservoir for many zoonotic viruses (with high virus diversity globally); they have the highest proportion of projected zoonotic viruses of any mammalian order. In addition, bat ecology favours virus circulation (large populations, birthing waves, and closely spaced communities).
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Bats are a known reservoir

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: Antibodies to bat coronavirus proteins have been found in humans with close contact to bats.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Antibodies to bat coronavirus

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: The closest known CoV RaTG13 strain (96.2%) to SARS-CoV-2 detected in bat anal swabs have been sequenced at the Wuhan Institute of Virology.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: CoV RaTG13 strain sequenced at the Wuhan Institute of Virology

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: There is no conclusive evidence for foodborne transmission of SARS-CoV-2 and the probability of a cold-chain contamination with the virus from a reservoir is very low.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: No conclusive evidence for foodborne transmission

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: Although rare, laboratory accidents do happen, and different laboratories around the world are working with bat CoVs.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Laboratory accidents do happen

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: There was no genetic or serological evidence for SARS-CoV-2 in a wide range of domestic and wild animals tested to date. The screening of the major livestock species was done across the country and provided no evidence for circulation of a related virus. The scale of testing in these species was such that widespread circulation is extremely unlikely.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: No evidence for SARS-CoV-2 in domestic and wild animals

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: Most viruses have been found in 2020 in low concentrations and are not amplified on cold-chain products. It is not clear what the infection route would be (possibly oral, touch, or aerosol).
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Low concentrations on cold-chain products

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: Although the closest related viruses have been found in bats, the evolutionary distance between these bat viruses and SARS-CoV-2 is estimated to be several decades, suggesting a missing link (either a missing progenitor virus, or evolution of a progenitor virus in an intermediate host).
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Evolutionary distance of bat virus

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: Although typical foodborne infections are thought to be restricted to enteric pathogens, there is some evidence that the oral route could lead to infection for SARS-CoV-2 from hamster infection experiments, and the virus replicates in gut organoids.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Oral route could lead to infection

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: Most evidence is for contamination of food with human viruses that are dispersed in growing areas through sewage or contaminated water for irrigation.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Sewage contamination

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: SARS-CoV-2 and related CoVs have been found to persist in conditions (time/temperature/humidity) found during trade of frozen products suggesting the virus could persist on contaminated frozen products.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Virus persists on packaging

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: Viruses similar to SARS-CoV-2 have been found in both pangolin and bats.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Similar virus in pangolin and bats

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: Regarding accidental culture, prior to December 2019, there is no evidence of circulation of SARS-CoV-2 among people globally and the surveillance programme in place was limited regarding the number of samples processed and therefore the risk of accidental culturing SARS-CoV-2 in the laboratory is extremely low.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Limited samples processed

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: Highly similar viruses have also been found in pangolins, suggesting cross-species transmission from bats at least once, but again with considerable genetic distance.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Evolutionary distance of pangolin virus

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: SARS-CoV-2 adapts relatively rapidly in susceptible animals (such as mink).
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: SARS-CoV-2 adapts in animals

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: The three laboratories in Wuhan working with either CoVs diagnostics and/or CoVs isolation and vaccine development all had high quality biosafety level (BSL3 or 4) facilities that were well-managed, with a staff health monitoring programme with no reporting of COVID-19 compatible respiratory illness during the weeks/months prior to December 2019, and no serological evidence of infection in workers through SARS-CoV-2-specific serology-screening.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: High quality biosafety

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: Food-chain transmission can reflect direct zoonotic transmission, or spillover through an intermediate host. Meanwhile cold chain products may be a vehicle of transmission between humans. The emphasis here is on cold/food chain products and their containers as potential route of introduction of SARS-CoV-2.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: Introduction through the cold/food chain

aif:I-node.aif:claimText: The Wuhan CDC lab which moved on 2nd December 2019 reported no disruptions or incidents caused by the move. They also reported no storage nor laboratory activities on CoVs or other bat viruses preceding the outbreak.
aif:I-node.rdfs:label: No incidents caused by lab move
